conclusion: To determine if the particle has returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark, we need to calculate the net displacement using the area under the velocity-time (v-t) graph.
The net displacement is the sum of areas above and below the time axis.
From 0 to 1 second: Velocity is constant at 2 m/s.

premise: Velocity is constant at 2 m/s from 0 to 1 second.

conclusion: From 1 to 2 seconds: Velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s.

premise: Velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s from 1 to 2 seconds.
conclusion: This forms a right triangle with base = 1 s and height = 2 m/s.

premise: Right triangle with base = 1 s and height = 2 m/s.

conclusion: From 2 to 3 seconds: Velocity decreases linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s.

premise: Velocity decreases linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s from 2 to 3 seconds.
conclusion: This forms a right triangle with base = 1 s and height = 2 m/s.

premise: Right triangle with base = 1 s and height = 2 m/s.
Displacements: 2 m (from 0 to 1 s), 1 m (from 1 to 2 s), -1 m (from 2 to 3 s).
conclusion: Total displacement = 2 m + 1 m - 1 m = 2 m.
The particle has not returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark.
